body: Let's leave this open, if someone wants to come review it great! but if not after a week or so I will merge it in.

Would it be possible to link to our new wiki page? Is this page http://netbeans.apache.org/wiki/DevFaqExternalLibraries.asciidoc the correct one?
(Source is here
https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans-website/blob/master/netbeans.apache.org/src/content/wiki/DevFaqExternalLibraries.asciidoc)

FWIW, do you know about:
https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NETBEANS/Experiment%3A+split+the+main+NetBeans+repository
?
Just a quick note, the 2 new classes have the wrong licenses - Should be using the Apache Licence, not the Oracle one.
Fixed.
Thanks for working on this! Are there any insights on what was the issue? Thanks!

Debugging through the code I recognized that during updating the ClassRepository for the JDK10 based profiled app I got two versions of the interfaces (java.sql.Statement and java.sql.Connection). Now during lookup if a class is a subclass the wrong instance was selected (not the one updated with the correct information about subclasses but the one with no information updated). This resulted in no profiling informations recorded since the relevant filter was never true.

I assume there may be more problems below the surface but this will take more time and a bigger change, so I just tried to fix this in a very local manner not affecting any other stuff in the core profiling library.

Thanks @jlahoda, yes, I used to have some memories of your work. Looks like it changes the content of `cluster.properties` - e.g. the former approach. If it is working, then sure, we can integrate your change. I am however more and more inclined towards keeping `cluster.properties` untouched - should I continue with my patch, I probably focus on that direction. 

But as I said: feel free to proceed with your work, if the system can be compiled without problems (my current patch cannot yet).
I doubt I'll myself have time to work on this (the page is 1.5 years old). I was mentioning it mostly if something there would be helpful. But please feel free to continue!

Why don't we simply comment out `jpb.setVisible(true);` at line 2380 or remove the `jpb` declaration completely? Do we need that progress bar for anything now that we don't communicate with any NetBeans Statistics server?

https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12922249/before_report_problem.png
When we click on Review and Report Problem button, above dialog is displayed with progress bar before either error page or exception report UI is displayed (based on whether there's a submit button in form on the page pointed by ERROR_URL.) This progress bar is required for above dialog.
OK, if the progress bar shows progress when connecting to the ERROR_URL it probably makes sense.

You need to strip the `*.SF` and `*.RSA` files from the META-INF directory. Please have a look at the `com.jcraft.jsch` module. There OSGI meta data is added to the plain jar. Maybe this would be an alternative way.
But why does the build ran successfully on Travis after my commits yesterday? Aren't the tests executed on this environment?

Regarding the com.jcraft.jsch module, yes you're right about the OSGi meta data that is added to the original jar, but it doesn't work with JGit! 

Look at the exception I got during my initial work on this PR (this was before using JGit as a NetBeans module):

I've found out why the `com.jcraft.jsch` module isn't working with JGit: it's because the export-package attribute is missing the version value (see http://wiki.netbeans.org/OSGiAndNetBeansMetadataMapping):

```xml
<attribute name="Export-Package" value="com.jcraft.jsch;version=0.1.54"/>
```
Indeed, after adding the version, the module is found by JGit!

I guess I could do the same for **SLF4J** and then leave **JGit** intact (no metadata alteration)!

What do you think?

I am not following your discussions fully, but the picture I got goes again to the question whether NetBeans is an [IDE for DevOps](http://wiki.apidesign.org/wiki/DevOps) (e.g. those who understand build system) or normal developers that only want to use *compile on save*...

What are the consequences of this patch? With a quick look I saw, that "being part of JDK" is determined by checking the path/package. JNA for example uses the package name "com.sun.jna", its classes are not part of the JDK. I understand, that trying to load all classes via the SystemClassloader to check if they are part of the JDK is stupid, but I think an alternative is needed. Could `Classloader#getResource` be an alternative?

I think this should be answered before merging.

Christian, thank you for your investigation. I'll answer your first question first:

> But why does the build ran successfully on Travis after my commits yesterday? Aren't the tests executed on this environment?

Travis does a full build - including tests. Even before the migration to apache not all unittests of the code base were excercised before a tree merge. Some of the unittests are currently broken and other just plain take much to long to run on each build. It is always a good idea to check the unittests of packages, you know that are affected by your change explicitly.

> _Analysis Result:_ The problem lies in the switch from bundle versioning to package versioning, which was not correctly mapped in the jsch case and is missing in slf4.

This sounds like a good route to take. Every dependency we can take without modifications is a good dependency (and before a nitpicker takes this on - every depedency we don't need is even better).

> users need to do dependency tracking themselves

I guess? Really it just seemed reflexive that if you were bothering to explicitly save at all, you would save the upstream part which defined an API before working on, and saving, the downstream part which called it. But maybe there is some way to salvage this situation if people rely on it; I would have to study it.

At any rate, I like the idea of stripping the sig files down to, well, signatures and putting the CoS functionality into a more superficial layer. Sounds like it would be more intuitive and predictable: the IDE would just be performing the final compilation of recently modified sources not covered by the last external build. Deserves a prototype, certainly a bigger project than this PR which was intended as a stopgap measure.

Missing from the initial comment:

The dependend modules are _form.binding_ and _hibernate_. Two exclusions were removed from the rat_exclusions.txt.

@matthiasblaesing no worries and thanks a lot for your feedback!

Duly noted regarding the tests and I totally agree with you about the dependency modifications! I'll remove the jar modifications I made to `JGit` and take care of `SLF4J` as well!  

The only other remaining issue is the missing servlet-api OSGi bundle but this dependency isn't even used by `JGit` (it was reintroduced by mistake)! I already warned the lead developer and he removed it but he hasn't released a new version yet! So I'll complete the PR as soon as he does it! See this [commit][1] for details...

[1]: https://github.com/eclipse/jgit/commit/a263bb11733de8d8113c5ad72030785bc95ebf33

Just refine the package list - e.g look for java/x instead of java/.

Anything that touches class loaders is likely to be orders of magnitude
slower for code that is called for every class in every jar. It's really in
the critical path.

-Tim

FYI, I've updated the patch to use 2-3 path elements to determine JDK
membership.  More than that would not be a smart compromise on performance,
especially considering that JDK-namespaced packages downloaded via Maven is
a vanishingly small corner-case.

https://github.com/timboudreau/incubator-netbeans/commit/dc7b9753640298fb34f9fc67f86128e01b3c0868

-Tim

Does this PR also update user & cache directories from dev to rc1?

One question: should 7f2fee1 and  e803780  both be there? It looks as if the second commit supesedes the first one. 
And a second question: The versions in trunk need to be bumped to (and higher than release90) - aren't they?

Both https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/commit/7f2fee14d01d34e91489ef0d09e6e97eaef416d3 and https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/commit/e803780f53529db9a55c41c9799b85e0c011cafe are intended. The reason is that there exist modules on the legacy update centers that are newer that the modules in the repository, and if we just incremented +0.1 (in release90) and +1 (in master), there would be legacy/old modules with the same spec. versions as our current modules. The intent is that 7f2fee14d01d34e91489ef0d09e6e97eaef416d3 would be merged to master as well, and then the spec versions. would be incremented again. So in the end, we would increment the spec. versions in master +2 and in release90 +1.1, and both master and release90 should be newer than any other existing module.

Checking it again, it turned out the spi.editor.hints on a legacy AUC has spec. version 1.43.0.7.55, so I'll need to move spec. version of that module even further on.

PR for master is coming later.
Thank you for the explanation - that makes sense.

Nitpick: we generally do not use micro version in javadoc tag. The .0 micro version is a placeholder, which allows to build system to generate spec version numbers, and increase version numbers (using that micro version) in release branches.
It's only necessary to use micro-version in javadoc, if the API change was introduced during patch releases, which is rather unlikely

Can you please post steps that would enable a macOS user to try out this patch? Walking through creating a "Hello, world!"-type app would probably suffice, leaving out the steps to actually sign the app.

What is the purpose of this:

```
cd "${0%/*}"
```

Also, I am confused by the comment "#make absolute and resolve symlinks" because the next line is a `cd` command.

Can the three `cd`s be combined?

Would something like this work:

```xml
<echo file="${dist.dir}/${app.name}.app/Contents/MacOS/${app.name}">#!/bin/sh
../Resources/"${app.name}"/bin/"${app.name}" "$$@"
</echo>
```

(I am not sure if this would affect dynamically linking DYLIBs that are included in the app.)
FWIW, seems that a change to spi.editor.hints is coming, and this PR will need to be adjusted after that.

@dbalek The first `cd` is to `cd` to the location of the script under `Contents/MasOS` since we are not likely to be in that directory. The second is to cd to the dir with the actual script. The third one cd's to the result of `pwd -P`, which makes the current path absolute and resolves all symlinks. That last one is done in the main script, but I felt it might be better to do that using `pwd` than to use the logic in the main executable since that is mostly what `pwd` is for.

Also, to test this, you will need to make a Netbeans Platform app, build it with "build-mac", and then sign the result with `codesign`. See https://developer.apple.com/library/content/documentation/Security/Conceptual/CodeSigningGuide/Procedures/Procedures.html to learn how to use `codesign`
OK, merged into `master` and created #555 to bring the same change into `release90`.
